webTitle: Is Foxtons the estate agent London deserves? | Andy Beckett

fields.bodyText: From the street, the Foxtons in Brixton in south London, like the estate agent’s other 55 branches, is almost all glass. Two great floor-to-ceiling windows, separated by a slender pillar, reveal a trademark Foxtons interior, unlike those of other estate agents: all pale, smooth surfaces, very bright lighting and very little furniture. There is a reception desk, a fridge of drinks for customers, a few clusters of modular white tables and chairs of the kind you might find in a loft apartment that was not quite as cool as it thought it was, and a couple of low display cases containing photos of two dozen properties for sale and for let. An unremarkable one-bedroom flat in a plain street nearby is offered at “£346.15 per week, £2,077 deposit + £420 (inc VAT) admin fee*”. The advertisement does not explain the asterisk. The Brixton Foxtons has been open for two years, glowing like an alien spacecraft, seven days a week and deep into the evenings, among the takeaways and bus stops and bargain clothes shops of Brixton Road. Parts of this area have been gentrifying for decades, but during the branch’s first month, someone scrawled “Yuck” on its windows. During the second, someone painted “Yuppies Out!” In April 2013, after a street party nearby to celebrate the death of Margaret Thatcher, someone threw red paint all over the facade. Later the same month, Foxtons temporarily hired security guards to prevent demonstrators campaigning against high rents and letting fees from entering the branch. The Brixton anti-Foxtons campaign has continued to escalate regardless. In July 2013, protesters managed to get into the branch and unfurl a “Yuppies Out” banner. This April, the branch was briefly occupied again by demonstrators holding placards that read “Social Housing Not Social Cleansing”. A few weeks later, during a generally peaceful anti-gentrification march on 25 April, half the frontage of Foxtons was smashed in. Six days later, there were still bits of glass on the pavement and the window was boarded up. But the branch was open for business. Young men in dark suits, with crisp white shirts and disciplined haircuts – “property negotiators” in Foxtons jargon – strode impatiently in and out, upright as young army officers, swinging their company car keys, working on buyers on their company phones. Inside, behind the spotless white reception desk, a young woman in heels and heavy makeup – the “office co-ordinator” – was waiting, as usual, to greet customers. At one of the equally spotless white tables, a nervous-looking client, a casually dressed man of about 30, was writing a list of properties on a pad of paper, as a negotiator watched from the chair opposite. In a short side street immediately round the corner, there were two fresh Foxtons for sale signs. As Chris Millington, a property business analyst at Numis Securities, told me: “Foxtons do very well down in Brixton.” * * * By common consent, London is one of the most frenzied and important property markets in the world: according to the Land Registry, it accounts for nearly half the value of all residential sales in England and Wales. But even in the intensely competitive field of London estate agency, Foxtons has acquired a unique, double-edged reputation: for relentlessness and innovation; for brashness and aggression; for bending – and sometimes breaking – the profession’s infamously loose rules; for doing almost anything to get a letting or a sale. “It’s a tough firm,” its founder Jon Hunt told the Daily Mail in 2009. (Hunt declined to be interviewed for this article.) Two years before, on the eve of the last property crash, he had sold his stake in the business for a reported £390m. Foxtons is not a huge company. Its share of the London residential market is estimated at between 10 and 20%. It currently has about 1,300 staff – the number expands and contracts as abruptly as the housing market itself. Its branches are outnumbered by those of rival networks: the national estate agency group Countrywide has 1,400 outposts. Foxtons operates solely in London and the Surrey towns of Woking and Guildford. Its branches cover about half the capital, including the centre, the most prosperous parts of west London, fashionable inner suburbs such as Hackney and Walthamstow, and more quietly rising outer ones such as Enfield. Each time Foxtons moves into a new area, and its logo of acid yellow and patrician green suddenly appears on “for sale” signs, on letters to local homeowners, on flashy new Foxtons premises, and on the loudly branded Minis the company provides for its negotiators, the character and status of that place seems to alter. There can be unease, even anger but there can also be a less publicly expressed excitement. As Ivor Dickinson, until recently managing director of one of Foxtons’ competitors, Douglas and Gordon, put it: “If you have a name as a really ruthless, sharky bastard estate agent, a lot of people, when they come to selling their house, will think, ‘I want that ruthless, sharky bastard.’” The swaggering success of Foxtons is partly a product of the double standards many of us have about property: complaining and worrying about the cost of it, while wanting to make as much as possible from it ourselves. The company is also a reflection of the modern British economy: short-term in its priorities, sometimes vibrant, London-dominated, property-skewed, socially divisive. The estate agent’s fortunes have become symbolic. Last month, the day the Conservative general election victory was announced, and with it the demise of Labour’s plans to increase taxes on properties worth more than £2m, it was widely noted by despairing leftwingers, as well as excited business reporters, that the Foxtons share price had leapt 12%. Since David Cameron became prime minister in 2010, Foxtons has almost doubled its number of branches, and more than trebled its annual profits, to £42m. When Foxtons became a public company in 2013, it was initially valued at £650m; within six months, demand for its shares had swelled that value to £1.1bn. Investors like Foxtons partly because it plays the property game two ways. As well as helping to drive the upward price spiral, it has also adapted itself to profit from the increasing number of people who that spiral has left behind. In 2014, 47% of the company’s revenue came from lettings, a far greater proportion than at most other estate agents. The 2014 Foxtons annual report notes with satisfaction: “The lettings market in London is particularly strong and acts as a useful counter to the more volatile sales market.” Among London estate agents, Chris Millington said, “Foxtons is showing by far the best returns. It’s transacting more than twice as much [business] per branch as the others.” Its influence is felt throughout the industry. “We’ve all learned from Foxtons,” Dickinson said. “We all try and do what they’re doing. But they are ahead.” Yet the company’s approach has also made enemies far beyond Brixton. Campaigns against proposed new branches have become a staple of London community politics – an easy focus for discontent about a steadily less inclusive, more money-driven city. On Twitter, there are @hatefoxtons and @AvoidFoxtons accounts, which seethe with customer complaints and general abuse (“total charlatans”, “Avoid Foxtons like the plague!”) and occasional acts of revenge (“told a traffic warden that a Foxtons mini was parked on double yellows”). This month a larger threat to the company emerged. Chris Townley, a former landlord of a property managed by Foxtons, became the first claimant in a class action against the estate agent. It alleges that Foxtons has overcharged landlords for repairs and maintenance, by deliberately hiring expensive contractors, and then adding to their bills an undeclared commission of up to a third. Townley’s solicitors, Leigh Day, claim that Foxtons could face a cumulative legal bill of up to £42m – the equivalent of its entire 2014 annual profit. The company declined to comment “on the specifics of this case”; but went on to say that “our fees are clearly laid out within our terms and conditions”; and that work on properties let through Foxtons was carried out by “carefully vetted and trusted contractors” who offered “competitive value”. The case may end up in court next year. In 2009, the Office of Fair Trading successfully sued Foxtons for extracting “unfair” charges from landlords. No matter how the latest lettings dispute concludes, it is a reminder that Foxtons is more vulnerable than it looks. For Foxtons, as for many British companies founded in the Thatcher era, new ways of doing things and a measure of ruthlessness have brought success; but of a volatile sort – and at a cost. * * * The guiding spirit of Foxtons remains its founder, Jon Hunt. He is a lean, reined-in man with a strong jaw, a drawling, slightly distant voice, and impatient, whirling hand gestures. “My old man was extremely tough,” he told the website Business Life in a rare interview in 2012. “He was Irish and came to London when he was 13. He was a runner for a legal firm … then he got into the army.” Hunt junior, born in 1953, soon learned to be just as adaptable and self-contained: while his father took up a succession of end-of-empire foreign postings, Hunt was sent to Millfield boarding school in Somerset from the age of seven. He loved Millfield’s emphasis on sport, but left the school at 16. He briefly joined his father’s regiment, the Royal Artillery, then moved on restlessly again, to work on building sites in France, and then back to England, to a job at a small estate agent in Woking. He was 18. It was the early 70s, the brief boomtime of Edward Heath’s doomed Tory government, and one of Britain’s periodic property bubbles was inflating. Woking, wealthy in parts, full of lush properties, but with a London satellite town’s transient population, was a good place to learn the trade. Hunt has a cautious side – “I will sit outside a property for six hours watching the traffic flow before I decide [to buy it],” he told the Mail in 2009 – and he stayed in Woking through the property collapse of the mid-70s. He came to realise that the final stages of such downturns, when prices were low but had stopped falling, was a good time to buy and sell houses – “when there’s blood on the street but it’s drying”, as he put it in the Mail. In 1981, with the British economy stuck in another recession, under Margaret Thatcher, Hunt, now 27, borrowed £30,000 from a Millfield schoolfriend and went looking for somewhere to set up his own estate agency. At the time, most estate agents were open at their own rather than their clients’ convenience – rarely in the evenings or at weekends – and their negotiating style, to Hunt at least, was pompous and unambitious. Ivor Dickinson, who started another estate agency not long after him, remembered: “We were part of an 80s generation, a generation of thrusting young things who wanted to shake up estate agency. We wanted to do everything better: more marketing, more use of information technology, better service for clients. Take it away from being a stuffy old profession.” The territory where Hunt chose to challenge the “walnut-veneer brigade”, as he called them, was Notting Hill in west London. In 1981 it was not an obvious place for a new estate agent. Since the second world war, the area’s towering Georgian terraces, subdivided and dilapidated, had first been a semi-slum of immigrants and bad landlords, then a counterculture stronghold for squatters and hippies and punks. A reputation for racial tension and street crime lingered well into the 80s. Yet Hunt saw commercial potential in the handsome architecture and the proximity to richer, more respectable areas of west London. On a prominent site on Notting Hill Gate, the main thoroughfare, between a popular cinema and the busy underground station, he took over the premises of a cheap Italian café called Topo D’Oro. The building was shallow and unlovely, really two knocked together, but it had a broad frontage, and across it in huge letters Hunt spelled out “Foxtons Estate Agents”. The name came from the Cambridgeshire village near where he lived. In contrast to gritty, bohemian Notting Hill, “Foxtons” sounded upper-class, traditional, rural – the first logo was a deep country green. Hunt hired a secretary and another young estate agent, and started trading from nine in the morning until nine in the evening. To attract customers and publicity, Foxtons sold properties for its first three months without charging commission. It ignored Notting Hill’s large lettings market altogether. “In our first year we banked £13,000 and [the business] cost us £46,000 to run,” Hunt told Business Life later, “so we were pretty close to bust.” A single big sale in nearby Knightsbridge kept Foxtons afloat. In 1982, with the economy finally growing again, as the Thatcher government’s heavy-handed move away from manufacturing towards property and service industries belatedly began to yield results, the one-year-old estate agent opened a second office, in nearby Fulham: like Notting Hill an inner-city area that was part of the emergent, glossier London. Hunt also hired a lieutenant, Peter Rollings. Rollings was bright, charming, slightly untidy; he became Foxtons’ fixer, its good cop. Meanwhile Hunt, always immaculate in a white shirt and dark suit, rarely smiling, stayed increasingly in the background. “You would never, ever see him in public,” Dickinson recalled. Estate agents in London, we’re sociable, we all know each other, have lunch together. But he would never lunch with us, sit on committees with us, get involved in industry awards. He’s not a barrel of laughs. He’s not got much time for niceties. He would do anything not to do the same as everyone else.” Foxtons did not advertise alongside other estate agents, but published its own promotional magazine. It did not charge the typical industry commission of between 1% and 2% in London, but 2.5%. In a fast-moving, often over-confident business – by 1989, the independent annual London Property Guide had fattened to over 600 paperback pages – Foxtons initially expanded slowly and carefully. The estate agent spent its first decade with only three branches, and took 13 years to move beyond its west London heartland. This caution turned out to be justified when the capital’s 80s property boom, like the wider Thatcherite economic bonanza, shuddered to a halt. But in its chosen markets, Foxtons could be recklessly competitive. From the mid-90s to the early 2000s, the Times reported in 2003, Foxtons employed subcontractors to pull down and destroy thousands of its rivals’ “for sale” boards. Foxtons admitted that it had done so for “a limited period in 2001”, and a police investigation followed. No charges were brought. It became clear that other London estate agents had also been waging “board wars”; only the thoroughness with which Foxtons had done so made it stand out. * * * During the 80s and 90s, Foxtons created a distinctive internal culture. Heavily influenced by Hunt’s personality and working habits, it endures, little changed, to this day. In its recruitment and working patterns, in its rewards and penalties, in its use of branding and digital technology, the company has been a pioneer for many of today’s British white-collar employers.At the core of Foxtons is obsessive commitment. Opening for longer hours than rivals means longer working hours for Foxtons staff. The issue dominates whenever they talk about their jobs. “The hours are completely insane,” posted a former lettings negotiator last year on an online forum where Foxtons employees gather anonymously. “You work 12 hours a day Mon-Friday PLUS every other weekend, with no lieu days!” A former sales negotiator added: “It becomes exceptionally difficult to maintain bonds and relationships with people outside [Foxtons] EVEN IF YOU LIVE WITH THEM.” For some staff the single-minded, almost cultish quality of Foxtons is exactly what appeals. Sarah Burgess (not her real name) left university in 2010 with a 2:1 in international relations. She had grown up in the country, and she wanted to live in London, work for a high-profile company, and learn how to do sales. “I wanted to do 70 hours a week,” she told me, “and I knew Foxtons had fancy offices.” A decade earlier, with its branch numbers now in double figures, Foxtons had centralised its operations around a new headquarters in Chiswick in west London. The facility is on an upmarket business park with large glass-sided, open-plan office blocks set beside lawns and an artificial lake. Foxtons’ current neighbours include the American oil conglomerate Halliburton and the jeweller Swarovski. Burgess went to Chiswick for an interview in 2011. “The head office is so vibey when you’re 18 or 19,” she remembered. “There’s music playing. It’s colourful inside – bright green. Everyone’s good-looking, everyone’s smartly dressed, everyone’s so happy! There’s buzzers going, people are collecting chocolates for making sales. You think, ‘This is a whole world I want to be part of.’” Foxtons recruits constantly and unfussily for its junior positions. “Sales experience is beneficial but not essential,” says a recent ad for a “trainee property negotiator”. Burgess remembered her fellow interviewees as “from all over the country, from Scotland, from Wales, from tiny villages. Quite well-educated people, and people who had dropped out of uni. Foxtons said to us, ‘We’ll give you a car and a phone. You’ll get to know London like the back of your hand.’ And it gave you a friendship group.” Burgess was offered a job as a lettings agent at one of its most prestigious central London branches. “There was banter at the interview” – life at Foxtons involves a lot of banter. Then Foxtons trained her. According to its website, the company provides an “intensive induction week for all new employees … It can even cover the basics like driving around London.” Even the most disillusioned ex-employees agree that the training is good. “Foxtons are very welcoming when you first join,” said one former sales negotiator. “They really do kit you out … put you in the right frame of mind so you are ready to go.” Burgess remembered: “It didn’t feel like you were going to be an estate agent, but [to work in] a really buzzy sales career. I don’t know if they used the phrase estate agent.” In 2002, at Hunt’s instigation, the company began stripping out the standard estate agent’s clutter from its branches: the rows of brown desks, the mountainous in-trays behind which discreet phone calls could take place. Ever since, Foxtons has offered its customers what it calls a “cafe-style” environment. Each new branch costs about £600,000 to fit out. The company’s London rivals typically spend half as much. In 2007 Hunt explained some of the rationale: “The office coordinator … gives [customers] refreshment and introduces them to a negotiator. These coordinators have been trained … to give a warm welcome consistent in all branches.” The types of free drinks, he went on, “are selected to be … sympathetic to our brand.” At today’s Notting Hill Foxtons, across the road from the original site, shiny tins of Italian Illy coffee stand on a shelf in a perfectly spaced line. Burgess’s workplace still took some adjusting to. “It was so clean. In a Foxtons branch, you will not find a piece of paper anywhere. You’re not allowed to leave anything on your desk – everything gets cleared away every night. And you move desks every few weeks. You never feel you can relax.” A similar surface orderliness – with its implication that Foxtons will bring order to the messy property market – marks the company’s carefully choreographed initial dealings with clients. If you phone a branch as a new customer, you will quickly be redirected to the in-house call centre at headquarters in Chiswick. There, a “new business consultant”, always polite, usually well-spoken and slightly caffeinated-sounding – Red Bull is popular with Foxtons staff – will try to extract personal details from you. This information is fed into the company’s electronic brain: “an integrated business operating system (“BOS”),” according to the 2013 Foxtons share prospectus, “ that covers all aspects of day-to-day business”. Customers and their data are then passed on to the appropriate branch. Meanwhile, the branches themselves also feed information into the BOS. “Everything is put in,” said Burgess. “Every note you make, details of every phone call.” The database, according to the prospectus, “as [of] 31 December 2012, contained approximately 3.5 million property records (which compares to London’s population of 8.2 million in 2011) … and contact details for approximately 2.1 million sales and lettings prospects”. Like other ambitious retailers, Foxtons began investing heavily in data collection and processing in the early 2000s. Its competitors are still struggling to catch up: “That massive call centre in Chiswick – it’s an incredible thing,” said Ivor Dickinson. “Most agents will have one person in the back of each branch whose job it is to chase up old [sales] leads. Chiswick has designated people making hundreds of calls a week each. And they sound a buzzer every time a lead is converted into business. Foxtons works on an industrial scale.” Yet the industrialisation of estate agency has its downsides. In the open plan centre at Chiswick, in Foxtons’ goldfish bowl branches, in BOS’s bright digital spaces, staff can never hide. Many former and current staff talk about being “micromanaged”. The most closely monitored numbers are each negotiator’s sales and lettings figures. Every Friday, for each cluster of Foxtons branches, there is a compulsory end-of-week meeting. Several dozen negotiators gather in a room and sit on rows of chairs in front of a big screen. “First, there is a pep talk – or you’re all told off,” Burgess remembered, “and then you get to shout out your figures. It shows on the screen where you are in the rankings. If you’ve done well, you’re buzzing. It’s one of the funnest parts of the week.” Successful employees are offered an elaborate sequence of bonuses. There are “trip targets” – sales attainments that earn company-funded skiing or Mediterranean holidays; and “car targets” – first a Mini, then a BMW, then a Mercedes. The slick Foxtons website shows packs of tanned, beaming, sometimes flirtatious staff holding beers, up mountains, playing beach volleyball. Burgess said that working at Foxtons sometimes feels “like being in a sports team, when you get a new kit. You all smell good. You feel you’re the dog’s bollocks.” Like you’re an elite? “No … a gang!” Yet less successful employees can suffer badly. Negotiators receive an initial salary of £22,000, but once they are considered sufficiently experienced, usually after about four months, they can earn commission: either 5% of Foxtons’ overall take on each transaction, plus a salary of £17,500; or 10% and a salary of £10,000. Most opt for the latter. It pays lavishly if things are going well: a negotiator selling a property for £1m earns a bonus of £2,500. But in lean periods the low basic salary, which has not changed for a decade, quickly threatens to make living in London impossible – not least because of the capital’s high property costs, for which Foxtons negotiators are themselves partly responsible. “You can have really bad weeks, months – it’s scary,” Burgess said. Foxtons has a more individualistic culture than its rivals, who generally pay higher basic salaries and sometimes hand out commission on a team basis. At Foxtons branches, the negotiators’ telephones are arranged facing each other, in gladiatorial rows. Despite this, or perhaps because of it, the young men in suits are always ducking outside to make calls. In 2006, Anna Adams, an undercover reporter for the BBC1 series Whistleblower, filmed a Friday meeting where, when individuals’ sales or lettings figures were announced under-performers were heckled. The documentary, which examined several estate agency firms, also included footage of a Foxtons induction session, in which a training officer told new employees: “We are associated with sharp sales tactics. People believe that we are going to try to sell them something for a lot more money than they want to spend … [or] somewhere that is completely different to their requirements. And funnily enough, they’re not wrong in that.” Adams got a job as a sales negotiator and was posted to the original Notting Hill branch. There she said she was encouraged to exaggerate how much properties were worth, in order to attract sellers; to invent high offers for properties, in order to persuade buyers to raise theirs; and to pressure buyers to use a mortgage broker owned by Foxtons, Alexander Hall – which the programme alleged was illegally passing details of buyers’ finances back to Foxtons, so that the estate agent could know how far to push them. The film also showed Foxtons staff forging signatures and altering sales documents with Tipp-Ex and scissors, to their own or the company’s advantage. The practices even had their own winking slang: “chop-chop”, or “simmering”. Eight months after the broadcast, and after threatening the BBC with lawsuits, Hunt admitted to the Guardian that there were “several things we had done in [the documentary] that were wrong”. But he went on, “I don’t think [they] were pervasive … and we straightened those out.” He dismissed the allegation that Foxtons and Alexander Hall illegally shared information as “total nonsense”. * * * Nowadays, Foxtons sometimes presents itself as an ethical business. A recent advertisement for a “graduate property consultant” says that “a clearly defined moral compass is a must”, and that the company is “an environment where we compete … but support each other”. Yet Foxtons’ approach to outside scrutiny makes such claims hard to judge. “We don’t do interviews,” Nicky Chute, the company’s head of communications, told me when I contacted her. Foxtons’ current CEO, Nic Budden, she went on, “is a fairly private person”. Ivor Dickinson, for one, doubts whether the company has softened that much: “In a highly commission-based environment, you are encouraging the negotiator to act for himself, not the client.” Sarah Burgess said: “Telling people you’re an estate agent is bad enough, but telling people you work for Foxtons is a double blow.” She left after 15 months. “A year and a half is a pretty good innings at Foxtons. It drains you. Everyone looks so much healthier after they leave.” The small minority who stay on for many years and climb the company hierarchy are known internally as “Foxtons till they die”. Hunt said to Business Life of his 26 years in charge: “We were very inward looking.” In 2005, Hunt’s lieutenant Peter Rollings left to set up a competitor, Marsh & Parsons. By 2007 even Hunt had had enough. “I was working 14 hours a day … I was in my 50s and it’s a young man’s game,” he told Business Life later. He sold his creation to a private equity firm, BC Partners, and shifted his energies to renovating Heveningham Hall, a country estate in Suffolk, successfully investing his Foxtons fortune in London property and, as if awarding himself a final “car target”, collecting Ferraris. A few months later, in 2008, for the first time in a decade and a half, London property prices began to drop. For the next three years, Foxtons suffered collapsing sales and staff culls. There were hasty and acrimonious shifts of ownership between BC Partners and the banks that had lent it the money to buy the company. At BC Partners, senior people began referring to Foxtons as “the F word”. There were predictions in the press – sometimes thinly disguised hopes – that it would go bust. The estate agent had become expensive to run. Since the late 90s, during the seemingly endless economic good times of the Tony Blair administration, Foxtons had increasingly moved away from Hunt’s original vision of step-by-step growth. Instead, it rapidly opened branches and annually redecorated its fleet of Minis. One design, “The 2005 ‘Camo’ Mini”, was described by the company as “inspired by ‘urban jungle’ culture” and “contemporary London street fashion”. Perhaps only an estate agent could say that about a mishmash of camouflage and country house green. In 2000, Foxtons expanded across the Atlantic to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Foxtons North America, as the offshoot eventually called itself, had its own Minis, almost 400 staff, and splashy advertising – such as a giant billboard above a tunnel entrance on the road back to New York City from the smart resort of East Hampton. But the company proved no match for dug-in local real estate agents and the late 2000s recession. In 2007, it filed for bankruptcy. “Foxtons is very good at what it does,” said the analyst Chris Millington, “but it can’t go against the whims of the property market.” * * * Like much of the British economy, Foxtons seems to have two modes: either overconfident expansion or panicky retrenchment. Since 2011, as the London house price bubble has reinflated, the business has resumed its upward path. But now it is a public company, with a fickle share price, and more of the detail of the estate agent’s performance is publicly available. In its latest annual report, a small graph at the bottom of page 19 shows that since 2010, as the company has opened branches faster than ever, its average revenue has dropped year by year, and by more than a fifth overall. In a world where valuing your own property is easy, thanks to all the online price data for comparable homes; and in a city where demand for housing drastically outstrips supply – where your scruffy Hackney terrace would probably sell if you just stuck a note in the window – the Foxtons model may not be sustainable in the long term. “They have always charged a premium [commission] for sales and lettings,” said Gavin Jago, a property analyst at the brokers Peel Hunt. “Online estate agents are starting to charge considerably less.” The rising online firm Purplebricks.com currently charges a maximum of £1,158 to sell a London home – less than a tenth of Foxtons’ average commission. Some senior estate agents outside Foxtons predict that, over the next decade, the market share of online firms will grow from a thirtieth to as much as half. Yet sharks never stop swimming. In April, on the same weekend as the window-smashing in Brixton, I visited another Foxtons, a brand new branch in Bromley, on the more sedate fringes of south London. It was a cold dark Sunday, not house-hunting weather, and every other estate agent I passed in the suburb’s grey centre was closed. But Foxtons selects its new markets with what it calls “granular” attention to local sales and lettings data, and increasingly sees its future in more affordable outer London. For all the company’s provocatively prosperous image, last year the average price it secured for a property was £544,000, only £30,000 above the value of the average London home. The Bromley branch was deserted except for two staff, both sleekly dressed young women, and neat rows of paper bags, each containing a flyer for the branch and a chocolate muffin. One of the women would spend the next few hours doggedly handing out the bags, bare-legged in the wind, to hundreds of passersby. I asked how business was going. “It’s 0% commission on the first hundred houses,” she said, with a rigidly eager smile. “We’ve already done 25 valuations.” There was already a Foxtons in nearby Beckenham. What if, I asked, a property came on the market midway between the two branches? Which one would deal with the seller and any buyers? She instantly turned deadpan: “It depends on who they call first.” • Follow the Long Read on Twitter: @gdnlongread
fields.standfirst: Even in the cut-throat world of the capital’s property market, Foxtons is notoriously aggressive – and successful. Is that why so many people are secretly glad when it turns up on their street?
fields.headline: Is Foxtons the estate agent London deserves?
fields.body:
From the street, the Foxtons in Brixton in south London, like the estate agent’s other 55 branches, is almost all glass. Two great floor-to-ceiling windows, separated by a slender pillar, reveal a trademark Foxtons interior, unlike those of other estate agents: all pale, smooth surfaces, very bright lighting and very little furniture. There is a reception desk, a fridge of drinks for customers, a few clusters of modular white tables and chairs of the kind you might find in a loft apartment that was not quite as cool as it thought it was, and a couple of low display cases containing photos of two dozen properties for sale and for let. An unremarkable one-bedroom flat in a plain street nearby is offered at “£346.15 per week, £2,077 deposit + £420 (inc VAT) admin fee*”. The advertisement does not explain the asterisk.

The Brixton Foxtons has been open for two years, glowing like an alien spacecraft, seven days a week and deep into the evenings, among the takeaways and bus stops and bargain clothes shops of Brixton Road. Parts of this area have been gentrifying for decades, but during the branch’s first month, someone scrawled “Yuck” on its windows. During the second, someone painted “Yuppies Out!” In April 2013, after a street party nearby to celebrate the death of Margaret Thatcher, someone threw red paint all over the facade. Later the same month, Foxtons temporarily hired security guards to prevent demonstrators campaigning against high rents and letting fees from entering the branch.

Related: Is Foxtons the estate agent London deserves? - Podcast

The Brixton anti-Foxtons campaign has continued to escalate regardless. In July 2013, protesters managed to get into the branch and unfurl a “Yuppies Out” banner. This April, the branch was briefly occupied again by demonstrators holding placards that read “Social Housing Not Social Cleansing”. A few weeks later, during a generally peaceful anti-gentrification march on 25 April, half the frontage of Foxtons was smashed in.

Six days later, there were still bits of glass on the pavement and the window was boarded up. But the branch was open for business. Young men in dark suits, with crisp white shirts and disciplined haircuts – “property negotiators” in Foxtons jargon – strode impatiently in and out, upright as young army officers, swinging their company car keys, working on buyers on their company phones. Inside, behind the spotless white reception desk, a young woman in heels and heavy makeup – the “office co-ordinator” – was waiting, as usual, to greet customers. At one of the equally spotless white tables, a nervous-looking client, a casually dressed man of about 30, was writing a list of properties on a pad of paper, as a negotiator watched from the chair opposite. In a short side street immediately round the corner, there were two fresh Foxtons for sale signs. As Chris Millington, a property business analyst at Numis Securities, told me: “Foxtons do very well down in Brixton.”


* * *

By common consent, London is one of the most frenzied and important property markets in the world: according to the Land Registry, it accounts for nearly half the value of all residential sales in England and Wales. But even in the intensely competitive field of London estate agency, Foxtons has acquired a unique, double-edged reputation: for relentlessness and innovation; for brashness and aggression; for bending – and sometimes breaking – the profession’s infamously loose rules; for doing almost anything to get a letting or a sale. “It’s a tough firm,” its founder Jon Hunt told the Daily Mail in 2009. (Hunt declined to be interviewed for this article.) Two years before, on the eve of the last property crash, he had sold his stake in the business for a reported £390m.

Foxtons is not a huge company. Its share of the London residential market is estimated at between 10 and 20%. It currently has about 1,300 staff – the number expands and contracts as abruptly as the housing market itself. Its branches are outnumbered by those of rival networks: the national estate agency group Countrywide has 1,400 outposts. Foxtons operates solely in London and the Surrey towns of Woking and Guildford. Its branches cover about half the capital, including the centre, the most prosperous parts of west London, fashionable inner suburbs such as Hackney and Walthamstow, and more quietly rising outer ones such as Enfield.

Each time Foxtons moves into a new area, and its logo of acid yellow and patrician green suddenly appears on “for sale” signs, on letters to local homeowners, on flashy new Foxtons premises, and on the loudly branded Minis the company provides for its negotiators, the character and status of that place seems to alter. There can be unease, even anger but there can also be a less publicly expressed excitement. As Ivor Dickinson, until recently managing director of one of Foxtons’ competitors, Douglas and Gordon, put it: “If you have a name as a really ruthless, sharky bastard estate agent, a lot of people, when they come to selling their house, will think, ‘I want that ruthless, sharky bastard.’”

Each time Foxtons moves into a new area the character and status of that place seems to alter

The swaggering success of Foxtons is partly a product of the double standards many of us have about property: complaining and worrying about the cost of it, while wanting to make as much as possible from it ourselves. The company is also a reflection of the modern British economy: short-term in its priorities, sometimes vibrant, London-dominated, property-skewed, socially divisive. The estate agent’s fortunes have become symbolic. Last month, the day the Conservative general election victory was announced, and with it the demise of Labour’s plans to increase taxes on properties worth more than £2m, it was widely noted by despairing leftwingers, as well as excited business reporters, that the Foxtons share price had leapt 12%.

Since David Cameron became prime minister in 2010, Foxtons has almost doubled its number of branches, and more than trebled its annual profits, to £42m. When Foxtons became a public company in 2013, it was initially valued at £650m; within six months, demand for its shares had swelled that value to £1.1bn.

Investors like Foxtons partly because it plays the property game two ways. As well as helping to drive the upward price spiral, it has also adapted itself to profit from the increasing number of people who that spiral has left behind. In 2014, 47% of the company’s revenue came from lettings, a far greater proportion than at most other estate agents. The 2014 Foxtons annual report notes with satisfaction: “The lettings market in London is particularly strong and acts as a useful counter to the more volatile sales market.” Among London estate agents, Chris Millington said, “Foxtons is showing by far the best returns. It’s transacting more than twice as much [business] per branch as the others.” Its influence is felt throughout the industry. “We’ve all learned from Foxtons,” Dickinson said. “We all try and do what they’re doing. But they are ahead.”

Yet the company’s approach has also made enemies far beyond Brixton. Campaigns against proposed new branches have become a staple of London community politics – an easy focus for discontent about a steadily less inclusive, more money-driven city. On Twitter, there are @hatefoxtons and @AvoidFoxtons accounts, which seethe with customer complaints and general abuse (“total charlatans”, “Avoid Foxtons like the plague!”) and occasional acts of revenge (“told a traffic warden that a Foxtons mini was parked on double yellows”).

This month a larger threat to the company emerged. Chris Townley, a former landlord of a property managed by Foxtons, became the first claimant in a class action against the estate agent. It alleges that Foxtons has overcharged landlords for repairs and maintenance, by deliberately hiring expensive contractors, and then adding to their bills an undeclared commission of up to a third. Townley’s solicitors, Leigh Day, claim that Foxtons could face a cumulative legal bill of up to £42m – the equivalent of its entire 2014 annual profit.

The company declined to comment “on the specifics of this case”; but went on to say that “our fees are clearly laid out within our terms and conditions”; and that work on properties let through Foxtons was carried out by “carefully vetted and trusted contractors” who offered “competitive value”. The case may end up in court next year.

In 2009, the Office of Fair Trading successfully sued Foxtons for extracting “unfair” charges from landlords. No matter how the latest lettings dispute concludes, it is a reminder that Foxtons is more vulnerable than it looks. For Foxtons, as for many British companies founded in the Thatcher era, new ways of doing things and a measure of ruthlessness have brought success; but of a volatile sort – and at a cost.

* * *

The guiding spirit of Foxtons remains its founder, Jon Hunt. He is a lean, reined-in man with a strong jaw, a drawling, slightly distant voice, and impatient, whirling hand gestures. “My old man was extremely tough,” he told the website Business Life in a rare interview in 2012. “He was Irish and came to London when he was 13. He was a runner for a legal firm … then he got into the army.” Hunt junior, born in 1953, soon learned to be just as adaptable and self-contained: while his father took up a succession of end-of-empire foreign postings, Hunt was sent to Millfield boarding school in Somerset from the age of seven. He loved Millfield’s emphasis on sport, but left the school at 16. He briefly joined his father’s regiment, the Royal Artillery, then moved on restlessly again, to work on building sites in France, and then back to England, to a job at a small estate agent in Woking.

He was 18. It was the early 70s, the brief boomtime of Edward Heath’s doomed Tory government, and one of Britain’s periodic property bubbles was inflating. Woking, wealthy in parts, full of lush properties, but with a London satellite town’s transient population, was a good place to learn the trade. Hunt has a cautious side – “I will sit outside a property for six hours watching the traffic flow before I decide [to buy it],” he told the Mail in 2009 – and he stayed in Woking through the property collapse of the mid-70s. He came to realise that the final stages of such downturns, when prices were low but had stopped falling, was a good time to buy and sell houses – “when there’s blood on the street but it’s drying”, as he put it in the Mail.

In 1981, with the British economy stuck in another recession, under Margaret Thatcher, Hunt, now 27, borrowed £30,000 from a Millfield schoolfriend and went looking for somewhere to set up his own estate agency. At the time, most estate agents were open at their own rather than their clients’ convenience – rarely in the evenings or at weekends – and their negotiating style, to Hunt at least, was pompous and unambitious. Ivor Dickinson, who started another estate agency not long after him, remembered: “We were part of an 80s generation, a generation of thrusting young things who wanted to shake up estate agency. We wanted to do everything better: more marketing, more use of information technology, better service for clients. Take it away from being a stuffy old profession.”

The territory where Hunt chose to challenge the “walnut-veneer brigade”, as he called them, was Notting Hill in west London. In 1981 it was not an obvious place for a new estate agent. Since the second world war, the area’s towering Georgian terraces, subdivided and dilapidated, had first been a semi-slum of immigrants and bad landlords, then a counterculture stronghold for squatters and hippies and punks. A reputation for racial tension and street crime lingered well into the 80s. Yet Hunt saw commercial potential in the handsome architecture and the proximity to richer, more respectable areas of west London. On a prominent site on Notting Hill Gate, the main thoroughfare, between a popular cinema and the busy underground station, he took over the premises of a cheap Italian café called Topo D’Oro.

The building was shallow and unlovely, really two knocked together, but it had a broad frontage, and across it in huge letters Hunt spelled out “Foxtons Estate Agents”. The name came from the Cambridgeshire village near where he lived. In contrast to gritty, bohemian Notting Hill, “Foxtons” sounded upper-class, traditional, rural – the first logo was a deep country green. Hunt hired a secretary and another young estate agent, and started trading from nine in the morning until nine in the evening. To attract customers and publicity, Foxtons sold properties for its first three months without charging commission. It ignored Notting Hill’s large lettings market altogether. “In our first year we banked £13,000 and [the business] cost us £46,000 to run,” Hunt told Business Life later, “so we were pretty close to bust.”

A single big sale in nearby Knightsbridge kept Foxtons afloat. In 1982, with the economy finally growing again, as the Thatcher government’s heavy-handed move away from manufacturing towards property and service industries belatedly began to yield results, the one-year-old estate agent opened a second office, in nearby Fulham: like Notting Hill an inner-city area that was part of the emergent, glossier London. Hunt also hired a lieutenant, Peter Rollings.

Rollings was bright, charming, slightly untidy; he became Foxtons’ fixer, its good cop. Meanwhile Hunt, always immaculate in a white shirt and dark suit, rarely smiling, stayed increasingly in the background. “You would never, ever see him in public,” Dickinson recalled. Estate agents in London, we’re sociable, we all know each other, have lunch together. But he would never lunch with us, sit on committees with us, get involved in industry awards. He’s not a barrel of laughs. He’s not got much time for niceties. He would do anything not to do the same as everyone else.”

Foxtons did not advertise alongside other estate agents, but published its own promotional magazine. It did not charge the typical industry commission of between 1% and 2% in London, but 2.5%. In a fast-moving, often over-confident business – by 1989, the independent annual London Property Guide had fattened to over 600 paperback pages – Foxtons initially expanded slowly and carefully. The estate agent spent its first decade with only three branches, and took 13 years to move beyond its west London heartland. This caution turned out to be justified when the capital’s 80s property boom, like the wider Thatcherite economic bonanza, shuddered to a halt.

But in its chosen markets, Foxtons could be recklessly competitive. From the mid-90s to the early 2000s, the Times reported in 2003, Foxtons employed subcontractors to pull down and destroy thousands of its rivals’ “for sale” boards. Foxtons admitted that it had done so for “a limited period in 2001”, and a police investigation followed. No charges were brought. It became clear that other London estate agents had also been waging “board wars”; only the thoroughness with which Foxtons had done so made it stand out.

* * *

During the 80s and 90s, Foxtons created a distinctive internal culture. Heavily influenced by Hunt’s personality and working habits, it endures, little changed, to this day. In its recruitment and working patterns, in its rewards and penalties, in its use of branding and digital technology, the company has been a pioneer for many of today’s British white-collar employers.At the core of Foxtons is obsessive commitment. Opening for longer hours than rivals means longer working hours for Foxtons staff. The issue dominates whenever they talk about their jobs. “The hours are completely insane,” posted a former lettings negotiator last year on an online forum where Foxtons employees gather anonymously. “You work 12 hours a day Mon-Friday PLUS every other weekend, with no lieu days!” A former sales negotiator added: “It becomes exceptionally difficult to maintain bonds and relationships with people outside [Foxtons] EVEN IF YOU LIVE WITH THEM.”

For some staff the single-minded, almost cultish quality of Foxtons is exactly what appeals. Sarah Burgess (not her real name) left university in 2010 with a 2:1 in international relations. She had grown up in the country, and she wanted to live in London, work for a high-profile company, and learn how to do sales. “I wanted to do 70 hours a week,” she told me, “and I knew Foxtons had fancy offices.”

A decade earlier, with its branch numbers now in double figures, Foxtons had centralised its operations around a new headquarters in Chiswick in west London. The facility is on an upmarket business park with large glass-sided, open-plan office blocks set beside lawns and an artificial lake. Foxtons’ current neighbours include the American oil conglomerate Halliburton and the jeweller Swarovski.

Burgess went to Chiswick for an interview in 2011. “The head office is so vibey when you’re 18 or 19,” she remembered. “There’s music playing. It’s colourful inside – bright green. Everyone’s good-looking, everyone’s smartly dressed, everyone’s so happy! There’s buzzers going, people are collecting chocolates for making sales. You think, ‘This is a whole world I want to be part of.’”

Foxtons recruits constantly and unfussily for its junior positions. “Sales experience is beneficial but not essential,” says a recent ad for a “trainee property negotiator”. Burgess remembered her fellow interviewees as “from all over the country, from Scotland, from Wales, from tiny villages. Quite well-educated people, and people who had dropped out of uni. Foxtons said to us, ‘We’ll give you a car and a phone. You’ll get to know London like the back of your hand.’ And it gave you a friendship group.”

Burgess was offered a job as a lettings agent at one of its most prestigious central London branches. “There was banter at the interview” – life at Foxtons involves a lot of banter. Then Foxtons trained her. According to its website, the company provides an “intensive induction week for all new employees … It can even cover the basics like driving around London.” Even the most disillusioned ex-employees agree that the training is good. “Foxtons are very welcoming when you first join,” said one former sales negotiator. “They really do kit you out … put you in the right frame of mind so you are ready to go.” Burgess remembered: “It didn’t feel like you were going to be an estate agent, but [to work in] a really buzzy sales career. I don’t know if they used the phrase estate agent.”

In 2002, at Hunt’s instigation, the company began stripping out the standard estate agent’s clutter from its branches: the rows of brown desks, the mountainous in-trays behind which discreet phone calls could take place. Ever since, Foxtons has offered its customers what it calls a “cafe-style” environment. Each new branch costs about £600,000 to fit out. The company’s London rivals typically spend half as much. In 2007 Hunt explained some of the rationale: “The office coordinator … gives [customers] refreshment and introduces them to a negotiator. These coordinators have been trained … to give a warm welcome consistent in all branches.” The types of free drinks, he went on, “are selected to be … sympathetic to our brand.” At today’s Notting Hill Foxtons, across the road from the original site, shiny tins of Italian Illy coffee stand on a shelf in a perfectly spaced line.

Burgess’s workplace still took some adjusting to. “It was so clean. In a Foxtons branch, you will not find a piece of paper anywhere. You’re not allowed to leave anything on your desk – everything gets cleared away every night. And you move desks every few weeks. You never feel you can relax.”

A similar surface orderliness – with its implication that Foxtons will bring order to the messy property market – marks the company’s carefully choreographed initial dealings with clients. If you phone a branch as a new customer, you will quickly be redirected to the in-house call centre at headquarters in Chiswick. There, a “new business consultant”, always polite, usually well-spoken and slightly caffeinated-sounding – Red Bull is popular with Foxtons staff – will try to extract personal details from you.

This information is fed into the company’s electronic brain: “an integrated business operating system (“BOS”),” according to the 2013 Foxtons share prospectus, “ that covers all aspects of day-to-day business”. Customers and their data are then passed on to the appropriate branch. Meanwhile, the branches themselves also feed information into the BOS. “Everything is put in,” said Burgess. “Every note you make, details of every phone call.” The database, according to the prospectus, “as [of] 31 December 2012, contained approximately 3.5 million property records (which compares to London’s population of 8.2 million in 2011) … and contact details for approximately 2.1 million sales and lettings prospects”.

Like other ambitious retailers, Foxtons began investing heavily in data collection and processing in the early 2000s. Its competitors are still struggling to catch up: “That massive call centre in Chiswick – it’s an incredible thing,” said Ivor Dickinson. “Most agents will have one person in the back of each branch whose job it is to chase up old [sales] leads. Chiswick has designated people making hundreds of calls a week each. And they sound a buzzer every time a lead is converted into business. Foxtons works on an industrial scale.”

Yet the industrialisation of estate agency has its downsides. In the open plan centre at Chiswick, in Foxtons’ goldfish bowl branches, in BOS’s bright digital spaces, staff can never hide. Many former and current staff talk about being “micromanaged”. The most closely monitored numbers are each negotiator’s sales and lettings figures. Every Friday, for each cluster of Foxtons branches, there is a compulsory end-of-week meeting. Several dozen negotiators gather in a room and sit on rows of chairs in front of a big screen.

“First, there is a pep talk – or you’re all told off,” Burgess remembered, “and then you get to shout out your figures. It shows on the screen where you are in the rankings. If you’ve done well, you’re buzzing. It’s one of the funnest parts of the week.” Successful employees are offered an elaborate sequence of bonuses. There are “trip targets” – sales attainments that earn company-funded skiing or Mediterranean holidays; and “car targets” – first a Mini, then a BMW, then a Mercedes. The slick Foxtons website shows packs of tanned, beaming, sometimes flirtatious staff holding beers, up mountains, playing beach volleyball. Burgess said that working at Foxtons sometimes feels “like being in a sports team, when you get a new kit. You all smell good. You feel you’re the dog’s bollocks.” Like you’re an elite? “No … a gang!”

Yet less successful employees can suffer badly. Negotiators receive an initial salary of £22,000, but once they are considered sufficiently experienced, usually after about four months, they can earn commission: either 5% of Foxtons’ overall take on each transaction, plus a salary of £17,500; or 10% and a salary of £10,000. Most opt for the latter. It pays lavishly if things are going well: a negotiator selling a property for £1m earns a bonus of £2,500. But in lean periods the low basic salary, which has not changed for a decade, quickly threatens to make living in London impossible – not least because of the capital’s high property costs, for which Foxtons negotiators are themselves partly responsible. “You can have really bad weeks, months – it’s scary,” Burgess said.

Foxtons has a more individualistic culture than its rivals, who generally pay higher basic salaries and sometimes hand out commission on a team basis. At Foxtons branches, the negotiators’ telephones are arranged facing each other, in gladiatorial rows. Despite this, or perhaps because of it, the young men in suits are always ducking outside to make calls. In 2006, Anna Adams, an undercover reporter for the BBC1 series Whistleblower, filmed a Friday meeting where, when individuals’ sales or lettings figures were announced under-performers were heckled.

Yet Foxtons’ approach to outside scrutiny makes such claims hard to judge. “We don’t do interviews,” Nicky Chute, the company’s head of communications, told me when I contacted her. Foxtons’ current CEO, Nic Budden, she went on, “is a fairly private person”.

Ivor Dickinson, for one, doubts whether the company has softened that much: “In a highly commission-based environment, you are encouraging the negotiator to act for himself, not the client.” Sarah Burgess said: “Telling people you’re an estate agent is bad enough, but telling people you work for Foxtons is a double blow.” She left after 15 months. “A year and a half is a pretty good innings at Foxtons. It drains you. Everyone looks so much healthier after they leave.” The small minority who stay on for many years and climb the company hierarchy are known internally as “Foxtons till they die”. Hunt said to Business Life of his 26 years in charge: “We were very inward looking.”

Telling people you’re an estate agent is bad enough, but telling people you work for Foxtons is a double blow

In 2005, Hunt’s lieutenant Peter Rollings left to set up a competitor, Marsh & Parsons. By 2007 even Hunt had had enough. “I was working 14 hours a day … I was in my 50s and it’s a young man’s game,” he told Business Life later. He sold his creation to a private equity firm, BC Partners, and shifted his energies to renovating Heveningham Hall, a country estate in Suffolk, successfully investing his Foxtons fortune in London property and, as if awarding himself a final “car target”, collecting Ferraris.

A few months later, in 2008, for the first time in a decade and a half, London property prices began to drop. For the next three years, Foxtons suffered collapsing sales and staff culls. There were hasty and acrimonious shifts of ownership between BC Partners and the banks that had lent it the money to buy the company. At BC Partners, senior people began referring to Foxtons as “the F word”. There were predictions in the press – sometimes thinly disguised hopes – that it would go bust.

The estate agent had become expensive to run. Since the late 90s, during the seemingly endless economic good times of the Tony Blair administration, Foxtons had increasingly moved away from Hunt’s original vision of step-by-step growth. Instead, it rapidly opened branches and annually redecorated its fleet of Minis. One design, “The 2005 ‘Camo’ Mini”, was described by the company as “inspired by ‘urban jungle’ culture” and “contemporary London street fashion”. Perhaps only an estate agent could say that about a mishmash of camouflage and country house green.

In 2000, Foxtons expanded across the Atlantic to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Foxtons North America, as the offshoot eventually called itself, had its own Minis, almost 400 staff, and splashy advertising – such as a giant billboard above a tunnel entrance on the road back to New York City from the smart resort of East Hampton. But the company proved no match for dug-in local real estate agents and the late 2000s recession. In 2007, it filed for bankruptcy. “Foxtons is very good at what it does,” said the analyst Chris Millington, “but it can’t go against the whims of the property market.”

* * *

Like much of the British economy, Foxtons seems to have two modes: either overconfident expansion or panicky retrenchment. Since 2011, as the London house price bubble has reinflated, the business has resumed its upward path. But now it is a public company, with a fickle share price, and more of the detail of the estate agent’s performance is publicly available. In its latest annual report, a small graph at the bottom of page 19 shows that since 2010, as the company has opened branches faster than ever, its average revenue has dropped year by year, and by more than a fifth overall.

In a world where valuing your own property is easy, thanks to all the online price data for comparable homes; and in a city where demand for housing drastically outstrips supply – where your scruffy Hackney terrace would probably sell if you just stuck a note in the window – the Foxtons model may not be sustainable in the long term. “They have always charged a premium [commission] for sales and lettings,” said Gavin Jago, a property analyst at the brokers Peel Hunt. “Online estate agents are starting to charge considerably less.” The rising online firm Purplebricks.com currently charges a maximum of £1,158 to sell a London home – less than a tenth of Foxtons’ average commission. Some senior estate agents outside Foxtons predict that, over the next decade, the market share of online firms will grow from a thirtieth to as much as half.

When a scruffy Hackney terrace will sell with a note stuck in the window, the Foxtons model may not be sustainable

Yet sharks never stop swimming. In April, on the same weekend as the window-smashing in Brixton, I visited another Foxtons, a brand new branch in Bromley, on the more sedate fringes of south London. It was a cold dark Sunday, not house-hunting weather, and every other estate agent I passed in the suburb’s grey centre was closed. But Foxtons selects its new markets with what it calls “granular” attention to local sales and lettings data, and increasingly sees its future in more affordable outer London. For all the company’s provocatively prosperous image, last year the average price it secured for a property was £544,000, only £30,000 above the value of the average London home.

The Bromley branch was deserted except for two staff, both sleekly dressed young women, and neat rows of paper bags, each containing a flyer for the branch and a chocolate muffin. One of the women would spend the next few hours doggedly handing out the bags, bare-legged in the wind, to hundreds of passersby. I asked how business was going. “It’s 0% commission on the first hundred houses,” she said, with a rigidly eager smile. “We’ve already done 25 valuations.”

There was already a Foxtons in nearby Beckenham. What if, I asked, a property came on the market midway between the two branches? Which one would deal with the seller and any buyers? She instantly turned deadpan: “It depends on who they call first.”
